issues.text: Whether the petitioner was given a reasonable opportunity of being heard before the cancellation of the import licences under clause 9 of the Imports Control Order, 1955, as required by clause 10 thereof?

anchor.surface_text: The point for decision is a short one and we need only state such facts as bear upon that point. The petitioners case is that the proprietor of the firm is a citizen of India carrying on a business of the manufacture of celluloid and plastic bangles, etc, at Bellary in the Mysore State.

issues.text: Whether the notice dated May 27, 1960 provided a reasonable opportunity of being heard by stating the specific grounds for proposed cancellation under clause 9?

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that the notice dated May 27, 1960, did not state any ground for the proposed cancellation it merely referred to cl. 9 without stating on which of the four grounds mentioned therein it was proposed to take action.

issues.text: Whether the letter dated July 2, 1960, stating grounds for action under clause 8, also provided reasonable opportunity against cancellation under clause 9?

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the petitioner it has been submitted, not without justification, that the letter dated July 2, 1960, related to a different matter, viz., the suspension of the grant of further licences under cl. 8 for which also a reasonable opportunity to be heard had to be given to the petitioner under cl. 10.

issues.text: Whether the petitioner was afforded an effective opportunity to show cause, including supply of relevant documents like the joint investigation report?

anchor.surface_text: Within 10 days of the receipt of the letter which was received by the petitioner on July 5, 1960 the petitioners solicitor asked for a copy of the joint investigation proceeding and the report submitted as a result thereof The letter also asked for other relevant documents in order to enable the petitioner to show cause.

issues.text: Whether the cancellation orders violated principles of natural justice embodied in clause 10?

anchor.surface_text: There was, in our opinion, a clear violation of the requirement of cl. 10, which embodies the principles of natural justice.

arguments.court_reasoning: Operative part specifies cl.8; difficult to hold it asks to show cause against cl.9 cancellation

holdings.text: The notice dated May 27, 1960, did not state any ground for the proposed cancellation; it merely referred to cl. 9 without stating on which of the four grounds mentioned therein it was proposed to take action.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Not disputed by parties; notice referenced cl.9 generically without specifying grounds, rendering it insufficient for show cause under cl.10.

holdings.text: The letter dated July 2, 1960 related primarily to suspension under cl.8, not cancellation under cl.9, as its operative part called to show cause why further licences should not be suspended under cl.8.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Operative portion specifies cl.8; references to prior notices do not clearly extend grounds to cl.9 action despite contextual links.

holdings.text: Even assuming the July 2, 1960 letter applied to cl.9, no reasonable opportunity given as petitioner requested joint investigation report and documents within 10 days but received no reply until after cancellation orders; orders issued prematurely without waiting for explanation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner promptly requested essential documents to respond effectively; authorities failed to provide them or grant time, issuing orders before response.

holdings.text: The petitioner had no reasonable opportunity of being heard before the cancellation orders dated August 3, 1960, in violation of cl.10 of Imports Control Order, 1955, which embodies principles of natural justice; cancellation orders are bad and must be quashed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative: May 27 notice lacked grounds; July 2 letter not clearly for cl.9 or ineffective due to non-supply of documents and premature orders; violates cl.10 audi alteram partem.

holdings.text: There was a clear violation of cl.10, which embodies principles of natural justice; the cancellation orders are therefore bad and must be quashed; writ petitions allowed.

anchor.surface_text: There was, in our opinion, a clear violation of the requirement of cl. 10, which embodies the principles of natural justice. The cancellation orders are, therefore, bad and must be quashed. We allow the writ petitions and order accordingly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl.10 mandates reasonable opportunity before cl.9 action; breached here, equating to natural justice violation, rendering orders void.
